Yes, chemotherapy can be a challenging treatment to undergo, and side effects are common. However, advancements in chemotherapy and supportive care have helped to manage these side effects and make the treatment more tolerable.

For example, anti-nausea medications can help to reduce nausea and vomiting, and advanced pain management techniques can help to manage any pain associated with the treatment. Supportive care like nutrition counseling, social work, and psychological support can also help patients to manage the physical and emotional impacts of chemotherapy.

Ultimately, the goal of supportive care is to help patients maintain their quality of life, reduce symptoms and side effects, and manage the disease effectively. It's important to discuss with your healthcare provider any concerns or symptoms you may experience during chemotherapy, so that they can provide the appropriate interventions and support.
